newsitem.title: ROMANIA: Romanian leader pledges to help abandoned children.
newsitem.headline: Romanian leader pledges to help abandoned children.

text.p: Romanian President Emil Constantinescu on Friday told a group representing nearly 100,000 abandoned children he would employ a former orphan to help tackle the problems of children in care.

"I will organise a competition to take on an orphan at the presidency to monitor what happens in orphanages with children like you," Constantinescu told 25 youngsters who ate sandwiches and drank juice at the presidential Cotroceni palace.
Constantinescu, a father of two, met the children at the end of a United Nations' Children's Fund (UNICEF) conference in Bucharest focusing on the rights of institutionalised children.
"This is the first instance of recognition at this level of the problem of institutionalised children," Maie Ayoub von Kohl, UNICEF representative in Romania, told Reuters.
Constantinescu, whose election victory last November ended seven years of leftist rule which followed the 1989 fall of communism, set child protection as a major goal for his four-year mandate.

"Initially, not a word was spoken about orphans and abandoned children. Then, the media reports started," Constantinescu told journalists after a one-hour chat with the children. "The time has come to do something."
Of one million children in care in 18 countries in eastern Europe, Romania alone has 90,000. Their number has grown by 20 percent in seven years of post-communist decline.
At least another 2,000 live in the streets of Bucharest or other major towns. Romanian children also account for 54 percent of Europe's juvenile AIDS victims and HIV carriers.
Romania is trying hard to shed its image of the early post-communist years, when television pictures of malnourished children in filthy orphanages were broadcast around the world.
Most children land in institutions after family breakdown or because their parents have criminal records or are long-term unemployed. Forty percent remain there until adulthood.

Despite budget cuts imposed by market reforms, authorities have attacked the problem by quadrupling monthly child benefit to the equivalent of $7 and extending paid maternity leave. Monthly salaries stand at about $80.
"I will become involved and hope ministers, mayors and members of parliament will follow," Constantinescu said after being photographed seated with children on the residence's red-carpeted staircase.
"The truth is that most of society is passive. We cannot sit and watch how society degrades itself."

Long-term institutionalisation, a legacy of communism, is both harmful and costly. Statistics show that each child kept in an institution cost the Romanian public purse an average of $1,700 per year over the past five years.
"Now that we have broken the ice with this visit, we will keep in contact," Constantinescu told the children. "Consider me your father and call me whenever you have problems."
